resources.string: What stage of your problem are you at?
I want to know what to expect
I am about to go to court
Sorry, Small Claims Court cannot be used for traffic tickets!
OK! Here is what you should know!

Go to court ten minutes early! It is very important not to be late. If you are the plaintiff and not there when the magistrate calls your case, he or she can dismiss the case. If you are the defendant and not there when the magistrate gets to your case, the plaintiff still must prove the case. But the plaintiff will have a much easier job if you are not there to tell your side of the story.

When it is your turn to speak, tell your story simply and truthfully. Focus on the facts, not your opinion. You should not try to act or sound like a lawyer. Just be yourself. Show the magistrate any evidence you have. After you have testified, your witnesses can testify and you can ask them questions.

Get together any materials you have that will help you prove your side of the story, including receipts, letters, photos, leases, cancelled checks, contracts, or ledgers. Bring them with you when you come to court.

Anyone who has first-hand knowledge about the case can be a witness - friends, family members, strangers, even a child. If they can help you prove your side of the story, they can help you in your trial. But they have to come to court to tell the judge themselves about what they saw or know.
\Practice what you are going to say. Before you go to court, practice. Think about what questions the other side and the judge may ask you in court. Think about how you should answer them.
If you have time, go to Small Claims Court to see what it is like. This can be especially helpful if you have never been in court. Small Claims Court is much more informal than other courtrooms.
